questions.question: Shrink and damages have been cited as meaningful gross margin headwinds—what are the top 2–3 root causes by category (consumables vs. non-consumables), and what leading indicators (e.g., incident rates, on-shelf availability, cycle count variance) will you use to prove the shrink plan is working over the next 2–3 quarters?
questions.why_it_matters: Shrink/damages can overwhelm pricing and mix benefits; investors need measurable, time-bound proof points that margin recovery is structural rather than cyclical.

questions.topic: SG&A drivers (labor, repairs/maintenance, safety, store standards)
questions.question: SG&A has been pressured by wage/labor, repairs & maintenance, and store standards initiatives—what portion of the incremental spend is “run-rate” vs. temporary catch-up, and what productivity offsets (hours per store, tasking, scheduling tools) can sustainably fund it?
questions.why_it_matters: Clarifies whether SG&A deleverage is a one-time reset or a permanent margin drag, and whether management has credible self-funding levers.

questions.question: You have discussed SKU rationalization and inventory normalization—what is the current SKU count vs. pre-reset, and how are you balancing fewer SKUs with in-stock and basket size (especially in consumables) without increasing substitutions or lost trips?
questions.why_it_matters: SKU and inventory decisions directly affect working capital, in-stocks, and comp sales; missteps can create hidden comp and margin headwinds.

questions.question: What are the most predictive store-level productivity metrics you track (sales per labor hour, on-shelf availability, queue times, recovery scores), and which operational changes have shown the strongest causal lift in comps and shrink reduction in test markets?
questions.why_it_matters: Links operational execution to financial outcomes and helps underwrite whether store standards investments will translate into durable comp and margin improvement.

questions.topic: Pricing / markdowns / competition (Walmart, dollar stores, mass/club)
questions.question: Given heightened value competition, what is your current price gap vs. key competitors on a like-for-like basket, and how much of your recent comp performance is driven by price investment vs. traffic vs. mix (including markdown cadence in seasonal/non-consumables)?
questions.why_it_matters: Determines whether DG is defending share through margin-eroding price actions or through improved traffic/availability, and whether markdown risk is building.

questions.topic: Digital / delivery economics (DG Pickup, delivery partners, last-mile)
questions.question: For digital (pickup and delivery), what are the unit economics by fulfillment mode (incremental sales, pick/pack labor, fees/commissions, shrink/damages), and what operational changes are required to make digital accretive at scale rather than a convenience-driven margin drag?
questions.why_it_matters: Digital can improve retention and trade area reach, but poor fulfillment economics can pressure SG&A and gross margin; investors need a clear path to profitability.

questions.question: How are you quantifying pressure on the core low-income customer (e.g., SNAP mix, EBT basket size, trip frequency), and what specific category/price-pack architecture changes are you making to protect traffic if benefits or discretionary capacity remain constrained?
questions.why_it_matters: DG’s core customer sensitivity is a primary comp driver; understanding SNAP/EBT exposure and mitigation actions is critical to forecasting demand.

questions.topic: Merchandising mix / non-consumables recovery / seasonal risk
questions.question: Non-consumables and seasonal have been volatile—what is the current strategy for balancing margin-rich discretionary categories with demand risk, and what guardrails (open-to-buy, markdown thresholds, exit timing) prevent a repeat of elevated markdowns?
questions.why_it_matters: Non-consumables can drive margin expansion but also create markdown and inventory risk; disciplined controls are key to stabilizing earnings.

questions.topic: Supply chain / DC capacity / in-stock and cost-to-serve
questions.question: What are the biggest current bottlenecks in the supply chain (DC throughput, transportation, store receiving/backroom constraints), and what is the expected impact of network changes on in-stocks and cost-to-serve over the next 12–18 months?
questions.why_it_matters: Supply chain execution affects both sales (in-stocks) and margins (freight, handling, labor); it also determines whether store standards initiatives can stick.

questions.topic: Store portfolio / new store returns / remodel strategy
questions.question: How have new store and remodel returns changed versus pre-inflation (build costs, labor, cannibalization), and what are the most important leading indicators you use to decide whether to accelerate, slow, or reallocate growth across formats and geographies?
questions.why_it_matters: Unit growth is a major value driver; understanding return durability and portfolio optimization reduces risk of overbuilding and margin dilution.

parsed_response.topic_coverage: Questions cover margins/shrink/damages, SG&A drivers, inventory/SKU, store productivity, pricing/markdowns/competition, digital delivery economics, and low-income consumer/SNAP exposure (plus supply chain and store portfolio).
parsed_response.methodology_notes: I anchored questions to recurring themes highlighted in Dollar General’s recent investor materials and earnings commentary (margin pressure from shrink/damages, SG&A/labor and store standards, inventory/SKU actions, and consumer trade-down), then translated them into management questions focused on root causes, leading indicators, and specific operational levers.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Reviewed Dollar General’s investor relations materials (earnings releases, presentations, and transcripts) for repeated drivers/headwinds and management initiatives tied to comps, gross margin, and SG&A.

Step 2: Prioritized questions by (a) magnitude of potential impact on near-term EPS and cash flow, (b) whether the issue is controllable via execution, and (c) whether management can provide measurable leading indicators and timelines.
